title: Epic will use an EU account to bring Fortnite back to the US App Store
summary:
Epic Games plans to use its Sweden developer account to submit Fortnite to Apple’s US iOS App Store, according to CEO Tim Sweeney.

On Wednesday, following the major ruling in Epic Games v. Apple that blocked Apple from collecting fees on purchases outside of apps, Sweeney said that Fortnite would return to the US App Store “next week.” (Apple has appealed the ruling.) But Apple terminated Epic’s App Store developer account in 2020 after Epic introduced an in-app payment system into Fortnite that ultimately led to the whole legal battle, so it was unclear how Epic might bring the game back to the US App Store until Sweeney’s post.

“We have conversed with Apple on the topic,” Sweeney said in an X post over the weekend. He noted that Epic created its Sweden account last year so it could launch the Epic Games Store and Fortnite in the EU. (That account was banned and reinstated in 2024 over another dispute.)

Fortnite won’t be back on iOS on Monday or Tuesday, Sweeney said. “Beyond that, we’re working as hard as possible and aren’t certain what day it will be ready.” Epic Games didn’t immediately reply to a request for more details about when the game might return.

Fortnite’s latest season, which is Star Wars-themed, kicked off last week.

filter_verdict.reasoning_summary: The article reports a concrete action by Epic Games to bring Fortnite back to the US App Store following a major legal ruling, which has significant implications for the app store business model.

seo_agent_results.generated_article_body_md:
## Epic will use an EU account to bring Fortnite back to the US App Store  

Epic Games plans to submit *Fortnite* to Apple’s US iOS App Store using its Sweden-based developer account, according to CEO Tim Sweeney. This follows a recent court ruling that blocked Apple from collecting fees on external purchases, prompting Epic to announce *Fortnite’s* return "next week." Apple had terminated Epic’s US developer account in 2020 after the company introduced an alternative payment system, sparking a lengthy legal battle. Sweeney confirmed Epic will use its EU-domiciled account, originally created to comply with EU regulations, to facilitate the game’s US return.  

### Why It Matters  

This move highlights the ongoing tension between Apple and Epic Games over App Store policies and fees. By leveraging its EU account, Epic circumvents Apple’s US ban while testing the boundaries of the recent court ruling. The return of *Fortnite* could signal a shift in how developers challenge Apple’s control, especially as regulatory scrutiny intensifies globally. However, with Apple appealing the decision, the battle is far from over—making this a critical moment for app store ecosystems.
